column2: What is the role of a system administrator?
column3: A system administrator (sysadmin) is responsible for managing
column5: and maintaining a company’s computer systems and servers
column14: A system administrator (sysadmin) is responsible for managing  configuring  and maintaining a company’s computer systems and servers  ensuring they are secure  efficient  and always operational.

column2: What is the difference between system administration and network administration?
column3: System administration focuses on managing servers
column6: while network administration focuses on managing and configuring network infrastructure
column14: System administration focuses on managing servers  operating systems  and system resources  while network administration focuses on managing and configuring network infrastructure  such as routers  switches  and firewalls.

column2: What is a Linux system?
column3: Linux is an open-source operating system that is widely used for servers
column5: and embedded systems due to its stability
column14: Linux is an open-source operating system that is widely used for servers  workstations  and embedded systems due to its stability  security  and flexibility.

column2: What are the basic commands for file management in Linux?
column3: Common file management commands in Linux include `ls` (list files)
column14: Common file management commands in Linux include `ls` (list files)  `cp` (copy)  `mv` (move)  `rm` (remove)  and `chmod` (change file permissions).

column2: What is a shell in Linux?
column3: A shell is a command-line interface used to interact with the operating system. Examples include the Bash shell
column14: A shell is a command-line interface used to interact with the operating system. Examples include the Bash shell  Zsh  and Fish.

column2: What are the different types of user accounts in Linux?
column3: In Linux
column4: there are three types of user accounts: root (administrator)
column14: In Linux  there are three types of user accounts: root (administrator)  regular users  and service accounts.

column2: What is a kernel in Linux?
column3: The kernel is the core part of the operating system responsible for managing hardware resources
column14: The kernel is the core part of the operating system responsible for managing hardware resources  process management  and system security.

column2: What is a package manager in Linux?
column3: A package manager is a tool used to install
column5: and remove software packages in Linux. Examples include `apt` (Debian/Ubuntu)
column14: A package manager is a tool used to install  update  and remove software packages in Linux. Examples include `apt` (Debian/Ubuntu)  `yum` (RHEL/CentOS)  and `zypper` (openSUSE).

column2: What is a swap space in Linux?
column3: Swap space is a reserved part of a hard drive used to extend the system's virtual memory. It is used when physical RAM is full.
column14: Swap space is a reserved part of a hard drive used to extend the system's virtual memory. It is used when physical RAM is full.

column2: What are system logs in Linux?
column3: System logs are files that record events and processes happening on a system. Common log files include `/var/log/syslog` and `/var/log/messages`.
column14: System logs are files that record events and processes happening on a system. Common log files include `/var/log/syslog` and `/var/log/messages`.

column2: What is the `sudo` command in Linux?
column3: The `sudo` command allows a permitted user to execute a command as the superuser or another user
column4: as specified by the system administrator.
column14: The `sudo` command allows a permitted user to execute a command as the superuser or another user  as specified by the system administrator.

column2: What is a process in Linux?
column3: A process is an instance of a running program. It has its own memory space and resources
column4: and Linux can run multiple processes simultaneously.
column14: A process is an instance of a running program. It has its own memory space and resources  and Linux can run multiple processes simultaneously.

column2: What is the `ps` command in Linux?
column3: The `ps` command in Linux displays information about currently running processes
column14: The `ps` command in Linux displays information about currently running processes  such as process IDs  memory usage  and CPU usage.

column2: What is the `top` command in Linux?
column3: The `top` command provides real-time system performance information
column14: The `top` command provides real-time system performance information  including CPU usage  memory usage  and process information.

column2: What is a service in Linux?
column3: A service is a background process that runs on a system to perform tasks
column4: such as managing web traffic (Apache) or handling database queries (MySQL).
column14: A service is a background process that runs on a system to perform tasks  such as managing web traffic (Apache) or handling database queries (MySQL).

column2: What is `systemd` in Linux?
column3: `systemd` is a system and service manager for Linux operating systems
column14: `systemd` is a system and service manager for Linux operating systems  responsible for booting the system  starting services  and managing processes.

column2: What is the difference between `init` and `systemd`?
column3: `init` is an older system and service manager
column4: while `systemd` is a more modern alternative that provides faster boot times
column14: `init` is an older system and service manager  while `systemd` is a more modern alternative that provides faster boot times  better management  and parallel service startup.

column2: What is SSH?
column3: SSH (Secure Shell) is a network protocol that provides secure remote access to a computer or server over an unsecured network.
column14: SSH (Secure Shell) is a network protocol that provides secure remote access to a computer or server over an unsecured network.

column2: How do you set up a static IP address on Linux?
column3: To set a static IP address
column4: you need to modify the network configuration file (e.g.
column5: `/etc/network/interfaces` or `/etc/netplan/`) and specify the IP address
column14: To set a static IP address  you need to modify the network configuration file (e.g.  `/etc/network/interfaces` or `/etc/netplan/`) and specify the IP address  netmask  and gateway.

column2: What is a cron job in Linux?
column3: A cron job is a scheduled task that runs at specified intervals or times
column4: managed by the cron daemon. It is configured through the crontab file.
column14: A cron job is a scheduled task that runs at specified intervals or times  managed by the cron daemon. It is configured through the crontab file.

column2: How do you restart a service in Linux?
column3: You can restart a service using the command `sudo systemctl restart [service_name]`
column4: where `[service_name]` is the name of the service you wish to restart.
column14: You can restart a service using the command `sudo systemctl restart [service_name]`  where `[service_name]` is the name of the service you wish to restart.

column2: What is a firewall?
column3: A firewall is a network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules.
column14: A firewall is a network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules.

column2: What is `iptables`?
column3: `iptables` is a command-line utility used for configuring firewall rules in Linux. It is used to filter traffic and define security policies.
column14: `iptables` is a command-line utility used for configuring firewall rules in Linux. It is used to filter traffic and define security policies.

column2: What is the `ufw` command in Linux?
column3: `ufw` (Uncomplicated Firewall) is a simplified firewall management tool in Linux
column4: used for configuring `iptables` rules with ease.
column14: `ufw` (Uncomplicated Firewall) is a simplified firewall management tool in Linux  used for configuring `iptables` rules with ease.

column2: What is DNS in Linux?
column3: DNS (Domain Name System) is a protocol that translates domain names into IP addresses. It is configured in the `/etc/resolv.conf` file in Linux.
column14: DNS (Domain Name System) is a protocol that translates domain names into IP addresses. It is configured in the `/etc/resolv.conf` file in Linux.

column2: What is NTP in Linux?
column3: NTP (Network Time Protocol) is a protocol used to synchronize the system clock with remote time servers to ensure accurate system time.
column14: NTP (Network Time Protocol) is a protocol used to synchronize the system clock with remote time servers to ensure accurate system time.

column2: What is the `df` command in Linux?
column3: The `df` command in Linux shows disk space usage for all mounted filesystems
column14: The `df` command in Linux shows disk space usage for all mounted filesystems  including the total space  used space  and available space.

column2: What is the `du` command in Linux?
column3: The `du` (disk usage) command shows the disk usage of files and directories.
column14: The `du` (disk usage) command shows the disk usage of files and directories.

column2: What is RAID?
column3: RAID (Redundant Array of Independent Disks) is a technology used to combine multiple physical hard drives into one or more logical units for data redundancy and performance.
column14: RAID (Redundant Array of Independent Disks) is a technology used to combine multiple physical hard drives into one or more logical units for data redundancy and performance.

column2: What are the different types of RAID?
column3: The common RAID levels are RAID 0 (striping)
column14: The common RAID levels are RAID 0 (striping)  RAID 1 (mirroring)  RAID 5 (striping with parity)  and RAID 10 (striping and mirroring).

column2: What is LVM in Linux?
column3: LVM (Logical Volume Manager) is a disk management system that allows for the creation of flexible
column4: dynamic storage volumes that can span multiple physical devices.
column14: LVM (Logical Volume Manager) is a disk management system that allows for the creation of flexible  dynamic storage volumes that can span multiple physical devices.

column2: What is a DNS server?
column3: A DNS server translates human-readable domain names into IP addresses
column4: allowing clients to access resources using names rather than numeric IP addresses.
column14: A DNS server translates human-readable domain names into IP addresses  allowing clients to access resources using names rather than numeric IP addresses.

column2: What is DHCP?
column3: DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) is a network protocol used to automatically assign IP addresses and other network configuration details to devices on a network.
column14: DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) is a network protocol used to automatically assign IP addresses and other network configuration details to devices on a network.

column2: What is SELinux?
column3: SELinux (Security-Enhanced Linux) is a set of kernel-level security policies that control access to resources in a Linux system
column4: helping to mitigate risks from malicious activity.
column14: SELinux (Security-Enhanced Linux) is a set of kernel-level security policies that control access to resources in a Linux system  helping to mitigate risks from malicious activity.

column2: What is a load balancer?
column3: A load balancer is a device or software that distributes incoming network traffic across multiple servers to ensure optimal resource usage
column14: A load balancer is a device or software that distributes incoming network traffic across multiple servers to ensure optimal resource usage  reduce response time  and avoid overload.

column2: What is a VPN?
column3: A VPN (Virtual Private Network) is a technology that creates a secure connection between a client and a server over the internet
column14: A VPN (Virtual Private Network) is a technology that creates a secure connection between a client and a server over the internet  providing privacy and encryption.

column2: What is the difference between TCP and UDP?
column3: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) is connection-oriented
column6: while UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is connectionless and faster but does not guarantee reliability.
column14: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) is connection-oriented  reliable  and ensures data integrity  while UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is connectionless and faster but does not guarantee reliability.

column2: What is a package manager?
column3: A package manager is a tool used to automate the process of installing
column6: and removing software packages in an operating system.
column14: A package manager is a tool used to automate the process of installing  upgrading  configuring  and removing software packages in an operating system.

column2: What is a backup strategy in system administration?
column3: A backup strategy involves regularly backing up system files
column5: and user data to prevent data loss due to hardware failure
column14: A backup strategy involves regularly backing up system files  configurations  and user data to prevent data loss due to hardware failure  accidental deletion  or disasters.

column2: What is RAID 0?
column3: RAID 0 (striping) splits data into blocks and distributes them across multiple disks to improve performance
column4: but it does not provide redundancy or fault tolerance.
column14: RAID 0 (striping) splits data into blocks and distributes them across multiple disks to improve performance  but it does not provide redundancy or fault tolerance.

column2: What is RAID 1?
column3: RAID 1 (mirroring) duplicates data across two or more drives
column4: providing redundancy. If one drive fails
column5: the data is still available from the other drive.
column14: RAID 1 (mirroring) duplicates data across two or more drives  providing redundancy. If one drive fails  the data is still available from the other drive.

column2: What is a system image?
column3: A system image is a complete backup of an operating system
column5: and data that can be restored to recreate the system in its original state.
column14: A system image is a complete backup of an operating system  applications  and data that can be restored to recreate the system in its original state.

column2: What is the difference between a hot backup and a cold backup?
column3: A hot backup is performed while the system is running
column4: whereas a cold backup is done when the system is offline
column14: A hot backup is performed while the system is running  whereas a cold backup is done when the system is offline  typically during maintenance or shutdown.

column2: What is a bootloader?
column3: A bootloader is a program that loads the operating system into memory when the system is powered on or rebooted
column14: A bootloader is a program that loads the operating system into memory when the system is powered on or rebooted  enabling the system to start.

column2: What is a file system?
column3: A file system is a method for organizing and storing files on a storage device
column4: defining how data is stored and accessed on the device.
column14: A file system is a method for organizing and storing files on a storage device  defining how data is stored and accessed on the device.

column2: What is the `chown` command in Linux?
column3: The `chown` command in Linux is used to change the owner and group of a file or directory.
column14: The `chown` command in Linux is used to change the owner and group of a file or directory.

column2: What is `chmod` in Linux?
column3: `chmod` (change mode) is a command used to change the permissions of a file or directory
column14: `chmod` (change mode) is a command used to change the permissions of a file or directory  controlling who can read  write  or execute it.

column2: What is a proxy server?
column3: A proxy server is an intermediary server that sits between a client and a destination server
column14: A proxy server is an intermediary server that sits between a client and a destination server  filtering traffic  providing anonymity  or improving performance through caching.

column2: What is a system update?
column3: A system update is the process of installing the latest patches
column5: and software updates to maintain the system’s functionality and security.
column14: A system update is the process of installing the latest patches  security updates  and software updates to maintain the system’s functionality and security.
